PRIMARY SCHOOL IN HOUGANG NEW TOWN
(Construction)

PROTECTION FOR LITERARY WORKS


    2. Mr J.B. Jeyaretnam asked the Minister for Law whether his Ministry is aware of the deep dissatisfaction felt by writers in Singapore at the lack of protection for literary works published by them and whether the Government proposes to do anything about this.

    The Minister of State for Law and Home Affairs (Prof. S. Jayakumar) (for the Minister for Law): Mr Speaker, Sir, we have received representations from local writers, and also other interested parties, on various aspects of our copyright laws.

    As the Member is aware, the law governing copyright in Singapore is still the UK Copyright Act, 1911, as supplemented by our Copyright Act (Cap. 187). Under these two Acts, works published in Singapore enjoy copyright protection. Both civil remedies and penal sanctions are available to deal with infringements of copyright works.

    The presentations from owners of intellectual property urge the revision of our copyright laws to bring them up-to-date and an enhancement in the deterrents provided against offenders. This branch of the law is being looked into by an Inter-Departmental Committee which my Minister has appointed. This Committee has been examining the implications and impact, both economic and social, of revising our copyright laws. Besides considering protection of literary works published in Singapore, it has also to consider the question of the protection to be granted to such works published elsewhere. Further there are issues relating to

Column: 735

cassette tapes and, with the advent of modern technology, computer software which require more careful consideration.

    The Minister has instructed the Committee to finalize and submit its Report as soon as possible. The Government will consider what action to take after receiving the Report of this Committee.

     Mr J.B. Jeyaretnam (Anson): Mr Speaker, Sir, the concern of the Singapore writers is over the lack of protection for their literary works outside Singapore. There are two conventions, the Universal Copyright Convention and the Berne Copyright Union. I understand we are not a signatory to either of these conventions. May I know if that is so? And if that is so, why is it that we are not a signatory to either of these Conventions?

     Prof. Jayakumar: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Member for Anson has pointed out that there are two international conventions, which is the case. However, in our approach to reviewing the law of copyright, we cannot approach it on a piecemeal basis. We have to approach the question of copyright in its entirety, for there will be far-reaching consequences. One of the matters before the Committee, which the Minister has appointed, will be which of these two international conventions should Singapore adhere to, whether we should adhere to them, and what will be the obligations and rights that will ensue from adhering to these conventions. But as I said, the question of copyright has many facets, and the adhering to an international convention is only one of the many facets which the Government is considering.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Mr Speaker, Sir, is the Hon. Minister of State able to say when he expects this Committee, which is studying his matter, to report, and when our writers may expect to see some protection for their literary works?

     Prof. Jayakumar: Mr Speaker, Sir, we should not rush the Committee, for this is an important area. It has to examine all aspects. It is not a simple matter of deciding that we want to protect a group of

Column: 736

Singapore writers. The complexities involved require careful examination. We must decide on the policy. It is not just a question of protecting the writers but we must also examine whether there are other costs and long-term disadvantages in one or other of the reforms. In trying to improve our copyright laws, we must ensure that the changes will benefit Singapore society as a whole. We must also look into what are the things we are going to protect - books, cassettes, audio tapes, video tapes, cinematographic films, computer programmes, and so on. We must also inquire as to the methods of implementation, whether the police have the necessary manpower to investigate, and so on.

    Bearing all these complicated aspects in mind, what I can inform the House is that the Committee is proceeding with its work expeditiously. It is not the intention of the Ministry to rush them into hasty conclusions.

     Mr Ho See Beng (Khe Bong): Sir, I would like to ask the Minister of State whether he has received any complaint from Singapore writers of international fame that they need this protection very urgently?

     Prof. Jayakumar: Mr Speaker, Sir, we have received representations from writers and groups of writers. I would refrain from passing judgment on whether they have acquired the fame of international status.

PERMANENT RESIDENCE
(Policy)


    3. Mr J.B. Jeyaretnam asked the Minister for Home Affairs (a) if he will set out the policy of his Ministry as regards the granting of permanent residence status; and (b) how many wives of Singapore citizens have applied for the status in the last ten years and how many of that number have been granted the status.

    The Minister of State for Law and Home Affairs (Prof. S. Jayakumar) (for the Minister for Home Affairs): Mr Speaker, Sir, our policy on the granting of permanent residence to foreigners is a strict one and is geared to protect and advance the

Column: 737

national interests of Singapore. Singapore is only a small island with one of the highest population densities in the world. We cannot afford to grant permanent residence as liberally as other countries endowed with larger land areas and natural resources. Our policy on permanent residence, like other Government policies, must give paramount consideration to safeguarding the interest of the vast majority of Singaporeans.

    We must also bear in mind that permanent residence is a first step towards acquisition of Singapore citizenship. It also carries other privileges, such as, in the area of housing, education, medical facilities, which are not available to other foreigners.

    Therefore, our Immigration policy on the grant of permanent residence has to be consistent with our national goal of promoting economic growth and maintaining a high standard of living for our people. Our policy on permanent residence seeks to attract foreign investors, skilled entrepreneurs, professionals and skilled workers who can contribute to our economic well-being. In addition, the Immigration Department will also consider applications for permanent residence from the foreign wives and dependants of Singapore citizens. The same consideration, as was explained in this House last year, applies, ie whether the Singapore citizen can well afford to maintain his wife and children so that they would not become a burden to the State. Permanent residence is a privilege and not a right. A citizen who wishes to sponsor his foreign dependants for permanent stay must show that he has the means to support them. This is important because we must discourage our citizens who can barely support a family from marrying foreign wives, and thus imposing a greater strain on our public housing, medical and social services.

    Sir, as to the second part of the question, the answer is that in the past 10 years, 27,199 applications for permanent residence were received from wives of Singapore citizens. Of these, 20,452 applications were approved.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am indebted to the Hon. Minister of State for

Column: 738

his lengthy statement on the considerations that must be taken into account. I would ask the Minister of State whether he would set out specifically the requirements that must be met before permanent residence is granted. Are there specific requirements or not?

     Prof. Jayakumar: Mr Speaker, Sir, there are requirements under the broad heads, but each case will have to be considered on its own merits. This is why, in my answer, I have set out the broad policy, for that is what the Member for Anson has asked - to set out the policy of our Ministry - and I have so set out.

AUTOMATIC RESCUE DEVICE IN HDB LIFTS
(Effectiveness of)


    4. Mr Liew Kok Pun asked the Minister for National Development (a) what are the number and percentage of lifts in Housing and Development Board apartment blocks that were brought to the nearest floor and had their doors opened by the Automatic Rescue Device thereby reducing the number of people trapped in HDB lifts during the recent island-wide power failure; and (b) whether his Ministry is satisfied with the effectiveness of the Automatic Rescue Device installed in all HDB lifts.

     The Minister of State for National Development (Mr Lee Yock Suan) (for the Minister for National Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, the HDB maintains 5,559 lifts. All lifts have been fitted with the Automatic Rescue Device (ARD), except for 159 lifts scheduled for replacement in the next two years.

    During the power failure on 5th February 1983, 5,320 lifts (or 98.5%) out of the 5,400 lifts fitted with the ARD were brought to the nearest floor where their doors opened automatically. The remaining 80 lifts were not activated by the ARD. This was due to:-

    (1) Defective ARDs - 28 lifts (or 0.5% of all lifts fitted with ARDs) had defective ARDs.

    (2) Tampering of lifts by trapped passengers - 52 lifts (or 1%) had ARDs in good working order but these ARDs

Column: 739

ceased to operate automatically for the safety of the lift passengers when attempts were made by the passengers to force the lift door open.

    My Ministry is satisfied with the performance of the ARD so far. The very low rate of defective ARDs clearly demonstrates the very high standards of lift maintenance and reliability of the ARDs. Nevertheless, the HDB will continue to monitor the performance of the ARDs to further improve their reliability. Trapped passengers should not tamper with lifts during power failures or lift breakdowns as this will only cause the ARDs to cease working, thus delaying rescue.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting: Mr Speaker, Sir, can I ask the Minister of State what steps are being taken to maintain zero defect of the ARD?

     Mr Lee Yock Suan: This is really a technical problem. In fact, I think we may have to ask the manufacturers how they are going to improve on the performance of their products. Nothing is perfect. But where technical improvements can be made or suggested to the manufacturers, I am sure my Ministry will be happy to do so. Also, the ARDs come from different suppliers. Some are more reliable than others. We will attempt to use the more reliable ones.

     Mr Yeo Choo Kok (Delta): Sir, would the Minister of State tell the House which figure is correct: the figure he just gave, or the figure of 5,518 which his Minister gave not long ago in this House?

     Mr Lee Yock Suan: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am not quite sure what figure he is referring to.

     Mr Yeo Choo Kok: The figure on the number of lifts.

     Mr Lee Yock Suan: The figure I mentioned is the latest figure - that the HDB maintains 5,559 lifts. We do knock down flats and so on. So there may be variations.

RESETTLEMENT OF SMALL BUSINESSMEN
(Alternative premises)


    5. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the Minister for National Development (a) if he will give suitable alternative premises to small businessmen and those persons engaged in businesses like boat-building, warehousing and food manufacturing who are affected by resettlement and whether he will consider re-locating them to places close to their residence; and (b) whether he is aware that, in some cases, those affected are not given any alternative sites.

     Mr Lee Yock Suan (for the Minister for National Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, businesses and industries affected by public development schemes are given resettlement benefits in accordance with the prevailing Resettlement policy. Eligible cases are allocated alternative office, shop, or industrial premises, depending on the type of activity. The HDB provides industrial premises for the relocation of a wide cross-section of industries affected by resettlement action. These industries include engineering, carpentry, motor-repairing and food manufacturing. However, it is not possible for the HDB to meet the requirements of some industries, a good example of which is boat-building. Boat-builders traditionally make small "sampans" or "tongkangs". As this is a declining trade and as boat-builders require scarce water-frontage land, the HDB is unable to provide alternative accommodation for them. Boat-builders affected by resettlement need to upgrade their activities to qualify for JTC industrial land or change their trades to those which can be conducted in HDB industrial estates.

    Large warehouses are usually not eligible for alternative premises because most of them are acquired with vacant possession. Owners of such warehouses can tender for URA sales sites reserved for warehouse construction, if they require alternative premises. Small storage facilities acquired on encumbered basis will be allocated alternative storage premises in HDB industrial estates, if the owners can prove that they qualify for such alternative accommodation.

Column: 741



    The relocation of affected businesses and industries depends on the urgency to clear the site and the supply of alternative accommodation. The Resettlement Department takes great pains to resettle businesses, wherever possible, near the residences of their owners. Where shopkeepers are concerned, there is less difficulty as most HDB shop premises have living quarters above the shop. In the case of industries and offices, it is not always possible to allocate premises near owners' homes owing to constraints in supply and the need for certain industries to be located in special areas.

    Businesses affected by resettlement action must qualify under certain rules before they can be considered for alternative accommodation. Generally, businesses not eligible for such alternative accommodation fall under the following categories:-

    (i) Cases where Business Registration Certificates do not bear the site address.

    (ii) Cases registered with the Registrar of Businesses after the cut-off date and where other documentary evidence does not exist to support their claims.

    (iii) Cases with Business Registration Certificates but which do not conduct business.

    (iv) Cases occupying premises acquired with vacant possession.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting: Mr Speaker, Sir, is the Minister of State aware that the term "boat-building" here implies that the boat-builders have upgraded themselves into building fibre-glass boats, like pleasure craft and small fishing craft? If that is the case, would the Minister seek the assistance of the agency, like JTC, in the relocation of such business which is affected by resettlement?

     Mr Lee Yock Suan: Mr Speaker, Sir, the answer would be, yes in those cases. Where they have upgraded to that stage, I think they would normally qualify for JTC water-frontage land.

     Mr Ho See Beng: Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like to ask the Minister of State whether he is aware that each time re-

Column: 742

settlement takes place, the business houses or firms suffer a terrible loss. Although the HDB could provide them with alternative shop premises, they have to rent them from the HDB. Could I ask whether or not the HDB would allow these people to buy the HDB shop premises so that they would not only able to carry on their business but also own the shop which was the case before resettlement?

     Mr Lee Yock Suan: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Member may be aware that where a resettlement case is given alternative rental premises, normally they qualify for rental concessions over a period of five years. In the first year, they pay 50% of what is known as the resettlement rental, which is 10% below the average market rate. In the second year they pay 60%; third year, 70%; and so on. So there is a five-year rental concession which is very significant in terms of the actual quantum.

    As for the premises, they also get compensation for their premises. Let us say, in a squatter area, the Resettlement Department will measure the size of the facility and pay them according to the standard rates. As to whether the HDB will allow them to buy the premises, I believe the answer would depend on a case-by-case basis.

HUDC FLATS
(New prices)


    8. Mr J.B. Jeyaretnam asked the Minister for National Development if he will explain how the new prices for the Housing and Urban Development Company flats announced on the 18th of February, 1983 were arrived at.

     Mr Lee Yock Suan (for the Minister for National Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, prices for HUDC housing are fixed no differently from those of other public housing. The Government adheres to the fundamental principle that the selling prices of public housing, including HUDC housing, should be kept within the reach of the applicants.

    HUDC housing represents the apex of Government-developed housing for the people. Ideally, the prices of HUDC flats should be fixed to enable the HDB to fully recover all development costs incurred, including land costs at market value, as well as construction, financing and professional costs. However, if the HDB were to determine HUDC prices on this basis, selling prices would have been much more than those announced on 18th February 1983 owing to the high cost of land in Singapore.

    To keep prices down, land costs have therefore been set at concessionary rates.

Column: 744

For example, land for Jurong East Estate in the Outer Suburban Zone was imputed at only $100 per square metre, while land for Bedok and Hougang Estates in the Inner Suburban Zone was valued at $150 per square metre. These values are much below the market values of comparable land for private residential development. In the 10th URA Sale, successful tenders for residential land in the vicinity of Bedok New Town ranged from $500 per square metre to $870 per square metre.

    In comparison with the selling prices of private flats in similar localities, the selling prices of HUDC flats in Bedok, Hougang and Jurong East are 40% to 50% cheaper in terms of per square metre of floor area. In the Bedok area, comparable private apartments are selling for about $2,230 per square metre, whereas HUDC flats are priced about 40% lower, at $1,238 per square metre for apartments and $1,424 per square metre for maisonettes. The average price of $210,000 per HUDC unit at Bedok, Hougang and Jurong East is well below market rates and within the reach of the HUDC applicants.

    For the exclusive estates of Pine Grove and Gillman Heights, public selling prices are fixed at $1,723 per square metre for apartments and $1,981 per square metre for maisonettes. These prices are still about 30% below the prices of nearby private developments. But selling prices of Pine Grove and Gillman Heights units should not be allowed to cloud the issue. These two estates are the remnants of a legacy of exclusive housing enclaves created by the former Housing & Urban Development Co (Pte) Ltd. The HDB inherited them when it assumed the function of developing HUDC housing. In future, HUDC housing will be integrated within HDB estates in accordance with the Government's objective of achieving a better social mix of communities.

    The determination of selling prices of future HUDC housing will follow the principles set for the first batch of integrated HUDC units at Bedok, Hougang and Jurong East. The Government will continue to ensure that these prices are kept within the reach of the people.

Column: 745



     Mr Jeyaretnam: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Hon. Minister of State says that the prices will be kept within the reach of those wishing to buy the HUDC apartments. But I see a report in the papers, only two days ago, that a number of people are dropping out of this queue to buy HUDC flats, and that less and less people are applying. So obviously it is beyond their reach. Less and less people will be able to afford the HUDC apartments.

    Secondly, the increases vary from 78% to 143% of the previous cost of HUDC apartments. Am I to understand from the Hon. Minister of State that the old company, HUDC, was running at a tremendous loss in selling those flats?

     Mr Lee Yock Suan: Mr Speaker, Sir, the number of people who have dropped out from the HUDC waiting list is about 52 out of a total of over 4,000 applicants. That is roughly 1%. I do not think one swallow will make a summer. It is not necessarily the case anyway, that people who dropped out did so because they could not afford it. It could be for a great variety of reasons. The hon. Member should think carefully through his arguments before confusing the public. This question of the price increase of 78% to 123% -

     Mr Jeyaretnam: 78% to 143%.

     Mr Lee Yock Suan: 143%, 1 stand corrected. This is because of the increase in the construction costs over the last few years. As you know, the prices of private properties and of HDB flats have all gone up because of the shortage of labour, the increase in the prices of construction materials, and so on. The HUDC were not making any losses, but it does not mean that costs have not gone up as much.

    As I have explained before, the HDB is in fact pricing the land at concessionary rates, and it is only on this basis that we are able to sell the flats some 40% to 50% lower than the market prices. This point about land values may not get through to the hon. Member. It seems to be a very difficult point for him to understand. But there is no doubt - if you ask any economist, he will tell you the meaning of this - that when we make land available to the public at subsidized rates, we should

Column: 746

really be considering the market rate. I hope the Member now understands the issue.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Mr Speaker, Sir, as I understand from the Hon. Minister of State, the reason for the increase was the rising costs in the construction of these apartments, and yet he has said that the HUDC was not making a loss when it was previously selling them at its prices. May I know from the Minister whether his Ministry or the HDB is able to present a costing of these apartments. I do not know what the great difficulty is. If the Ministry or the HDB wants a form on how this costing is arrived at, I will be quite happy to give them to show how it can be done.

     Mr Lee Yock Suan: Mr Speaker, Sir, there is no difficulty at all in providing the costing. If hon. Members want it, we will be happy to provide it. In fact, I am surprised to hear the Member now saying that there is no difficulty. If he recalls, sometime ago when we were debating this question of HDB prices, he was asking, "How does HDB price it?", because we have no accounting system and so on. We then asked him at that time whether he wanted us to price the flats for the Anson residents according to the true costs, and we did not get any answer from him. So now, I do not see how we should be asking him to give us a method to cost the houses.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: You have the difficulty.

SINGAPORE ARMED FORCES
(Adoption of informal and people-oriented management style)


    9. Mr Sia Khoon Seong asked the Minister of Defence and Second Minister for Health if the informal and "people oriented" management style adopted by the Singapore Armed Forces will not result in a drop in disciplinary standards and how the Ministry of Defence will ensure that high disciplinary standards are maintained; why the approach was considered necessary; and how the Ministry sees the National Servicemen responding to this change.

Column: 747



     The Minister of State of Defence (Dr Yeo Ning Hong) (for the Minister of Defence and Second Minister for Health): Mr Speaker, Sir, the SAF is a citizen armed forces manned and led by Singaporeans for the defence of Singaporeans. Its practices must, therefore, be responsive to our changing social environment and population profile. Our soldiers are now much better educated than they were some 10-15 years ago. Hence, the SAF needs a management philosophy which, while maintaining military discipline, is characterized by close rapport between, and a high esprit de corps among all ranks. Such a philosophy requires mutual understanding, close interaction and good communication. The soldier sees the need to comply with orders. The Commander is open to innovations and suggestions from all the men.

    A people-oriented management incorporating such an approach will not result in a drop in discipline.
